abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Capacity
            Development Project for Mongolia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            Bank and Government should be realistic about the risk of
            procurement delays at the outset to avoid administratively
            costly extensions or squeezing the timeframe for
            implementation. The Government and Bank should extend
            projects if there is a reasonable chance of increasing the
            developmental impact. The Bank should be realistic about the
            risks related to designing financial sector projects that
            target only a few banks. Monitoring and evaluation
            indicators must be sufficiently demanding if they are to
            serve as useful tools for a project. For a successful
            privatization, government must maintain a commitment to a
            controlled and transparent privatization process. The
            savings bank privatization in Mongolia demonstrated the
            well-known lesson that the most important factor affecting
            outcome is not the government's development of a good
            action plan, but the Government's commitment to fully
            implement the plan.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Financial Capacity
            Development Project is to support institutional capacity
            building of the Mongolian banking sector to reduce systemic
            risks and enhance financial intermediation. There are three
            project components. First, the Commercial Bank Risk
            Management component assists the participating banks in
            re-engineering their lending process and creating a strong
            credit culture. It will enhance the effectiveness of
            commercial banks' credit risk management and
            cxompliance with Bank of Mongolia regulations and
            international banking practices. For each of the three
            selected banks, an international specialist will be retained
            to work full time in a senior management position;
            allocations will also be made for short-term staff
            secondment in foreign commercial banks and risk management
            systems upgrading. Second, the payents systems modernization
            component assures the availability of an appropriate set of
            cost-effective payments systems and payments instruments
            that satisfy the evolving needs of all sectors of the
            economy with particular emphasis on the needs of government,
            business, and individual consumers to make and receive
            non-cash payments. Third, the Savings Bank Resolution
            component assists the governemtn to develop and implement a
            carefully managed divestiture process of the Savings Bank,
            to diversify systemic risks and reduce government subsidies.
